xxl.core.collections.containers
Class MapContainer

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.containers.AbstractContainer
      xxl.core.collections.containers.MapContainer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Container
public class MapContainer
extends AbstractContainer

This class provides an implementation of the Container interface that internally uses a map to store the (id,*)-elements. Most methods directly call the methods of the internally used map.

This class supports a clone mode that means every Object which is inserted into/retrieved from the map is cloned. This clone method must use the reflection API because clone is protected inside the class Object. If you do not clone the objects, then a change of the inserted Object also changes the Object inside the Container. So you might have side effects which certainly will cause a different behaviour when you switch to an external Container (which cannot have side effects).

If you want to develop an application which works on external memory, then test your application with a MapContainer without clone mode first, then with the clone mode and then switch to the external Container.

The iterators returned by this class' ids and objects methods are fail-fast: if the container is modified at any time after the iterator is created, in any way except through the iterator's own remove method, the iterator throws a ConcurrentModificationException. Thus, in the face of concurrent modification, the iterator fails quickly and cleanly, rather than risking arbitrary, non-deterministic behavior at an undetermined time in the future.

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new map container (that uses a hash map to store its elements per default)

     MapContainer container = new MapContainer();

     // create an iteration over the Integer between 0 and 19

     Iterator iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator and save the returned iterator of the ids

     iterator = container.insertAll(iterator);

     // print all elements of the container

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(container.get(iterator.next()));

     // close the open container after use

     container.close();
Usage example (2). 
     // create a new map container that uses a tree map to store its elements

     container = new MapContainer(new java.util.TreeMap());

     // create an iteration over the Integer between 0 and 19

     iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     iterator = container.insertAll(iterator);

     // consume iterator in order to insert elements (lazy evaluation)

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         iterator.next();

     // generate an iteration over the ids of the container

     iterator = container.ids();

     // look at every id and ...

     while (iterator.hasNext()) {
         Object id = iterator.next();
         int i = ((Integer)container.get(id)).intValue();

         // remove every Integer that is smaller than 5

         if (i < 5) {
             container.remove(id);

             // uddate the iteration over the ids because the queue has been modified

             iterator = container.ids();
         }
         else

             // update every odd Integer by multiplying it with 10

             if (i%2 != 0)
                 container.update(id, new Integer(i*10));
     }

     // generate an iteration over the objects of the container

     iterator = container.objects();

     // print all elements of the container

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(iterator.next());

     // close the open container after use

     container.close();

See Also:
Converter, Function, HashMap, Iterator, LongConverter, Map, Map.Entry, Mapper, NoSuchElementException

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function<Object,MapContainer> FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new MapContainer. It may be invoked with a parameter list (for further details see Function) of maps, an iterator or without any parameters. A parameter list of maps will be used to initialize the internally used map with the map at index 0 and an iterator will be used to insert the contained elements into the new MapContainer.

See Also:
Function

counter

protected long counter
A counter that is used to create unique ids. Everytime an object is inserted into the container the counter is increased and a Long object with the actual value of the counter is returned as id.

map

protected Map map
The map is internally used to store the (id,*)-elements of the container.

cloneObjects

protected boolean cloneObjects
Flag which determines if every object is cloned before storing and before returning it.

empty

protected static final Object empty
A unique object used to identify mappings where no object has been assigned to so far.

Constructor Detail

MapContainer

public MapContainer(Map map,
                    boolean cloneObjects)
Constructs a container containing the (id,*)-elements of the map. The specified map is internally used to store the entries of the container.

Parameters:
map - the map that is used to initialize the internally used map.
cloneObjects - determines if every object is cloned before storing and before returning it. The clone mode is a lot slower, because reflection is needed to call the protected clone method.

MapContainer

public MapContainer(Map map)
Constructs a container containing the (id,*)-elements of the map. The specified map is internally used to store the entries of the container. Objects are not cloned before insertion and before retrieval. So beware of side effects.

Parameters:
map - the map that is used to initialize the internally used map.

MapContainer

public MapContainer(boolean cloneObjects)
Constructs an empty container. This container instantiates a new HashMap in order to store its (id,*)-elements.

Parameters:
cloneObjects - determines if every object is cloned before storing and before returning it. The clone mode is a lot slower, because reflection is needed to call the protected clone Method.

MapContainer

public MapContainer()
Constructs an empty container. This container instantiates a new HashMap in order to store its (id,*)-elements. Objects are not cloned before insertion and before retrieval. So beware of side effects.

Method Detail

objectIdConverter

public FixedSizeConverter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Because this container is returning Long objects as ids the converter LongConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE is returned.

Specified by:
objectIdConverter in interface Container
Specified by:
objectIdConverter in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.
See Also:
LongConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE

getIdSize

public int getIdSize()
Returns the size of the ids generated by this container in bytes, which is 8.

Specified by:

Overrides:

8

public void clear()
Removes all elements from this container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.

get

public Object get(Object id,
                  boolean unfix)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown if there is not object stored with this id. The parameter unfix has no function because this container is unbuffered.

Specified by:
get in interface Container
Specified by:
get in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

ids

public Iterator ids()
Returns an iterator that delivers all the identifiers of the container that are in use.

Specified by:
ids in interface Container
Specified by:
ids in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
an iterator of all identifiers used by this container.

insert

public Object insert(Object object,
                     boolean unfix)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object. This container uses a counter to generate an unique id. Everytime an object is inserted into the container the counter is increased and a Long object with the actual value of the counter is returned as id. So the identifier will not be reused again when the object is deleted from the container. The parameter unfix has no function because this container is unbuffered.

Specified by:
insert in interface Container
Overrides:
insert in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
object - is the new object.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

isUsed

public boolean isUsed(Object id)
Checks whether the id has been returned previously by a call to insert or reserve and hasn't been removed so far.

Specified by:
isUsed in interface Container
Specified by:
isUsed in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - the id to be checked.
Returns:
true exactly if the id is still in use.

remove

public void remove(Object id)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Removes the object with identifier id. An exception is thrown when an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

Specified by:
remove in interface Container
Specified by:
remove in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - an identifier of an object.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

reserve

public Object reserve(Function getObject)
Reserves an id for subsequent use. The container may or may not need an object to be able to reserve an id, depending on the implementation. If so, it will call the parameterless function provided by the parameter getObject.

Specified by:
reserve in interface Container
Specified by:
reserve in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
getObject - A parameterless function providing the object for that an id should be reserved.
Returns:
the reserved id.

update

public void update(Object id,
                   Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

Specified by:
update in interface Container
Specified by:
update in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a MapContainer. It can also be used to test the functionality of a MapContainer.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
